sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Chronic myeloid leukemia, Chronic or accelerated phase with resistance to or intolerance of 2 or more tyrosine kinase inhibitors: induction, 1.25 mg/m(2) SUBQ twice daily for 14 consecutive days every 28 days until a hematologic response is achieved
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia, Chronic or accelerated phase with resistance to or intolerance of 2 or more tyrosine kinase inhibitors: maintenance, 1.25 mg/m(2) SUBQ twice daily for 7 consecutive days every 28 days as long as a clinical benefit is maintained

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• neutropenia, grade 4: delay next cycle until absolute neutrophil count is 1 x 10(9)/L or greater and reduce number of dosing days for next cycle by 2 days
  • thrombocytopenia, grade 3: delay next cycle until platelet count is 50 x 10(9)/L or greater and reduce number of dosing days for next cycle by 2 days

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Chronic myeloid leukemia, Chronic or accelerated phase with resistance to or intolerance of 2 or more tyrosine kinase inhibitors

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anemia, Grade 3 or 4 including fatalities, has been reported; monitoring recommended; if occurs, delaying next cycle and/or reducing days of therapy may be necessary
  • diabetes mellitus, poorly controlled; avoid use
  • elderly (65 years of age or older); increased risk for hematologic toxicity
  • hemorrhage, cerebral (some fatal) and gastrointestinal (severe but non-fatal), has been reported; increased risk with severe thrombocytopenia; monitoring recommended
  • hyperglycemia, Grade 3 or 4, has been reported; monitoring recommended, particularly in patients with diabetes or risk factors
  • neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 including fatalities, has been reported; increases risk for infection; monitoring recommended; delaying next cycle and/or reducing days of therapy may be required
  • platelet count less than 50,000/microliter; avoid concomitant anticoagulants, aspirin, and NSAIDs; increased bleeding risk
  • pregnancy should be avoided
  • thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 including fatalities, has been reported; increased risk for hemorrhage; monitoring recommended; delaying next cycle and/or reducing days of therapy may be required
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Increased uric acid level, Grade 3 or 4 (56% to 57%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (35% to 42%), Nausea (27% to 32%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, All grades (51% to 61%), Febrile neutropenia, All grades (10% to 20%), Neutropenia, All grades (20% to 50%), Thrombocytopenia, All grades (56% to 74%)
  • Other:Fatigue (26% to 31%), Fever (24% to 29%), Infectious disease (46% to 56%), Infusion reaction (22% to 34%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Acute coronary syndrome (1% to less than 10%), Cardiac dysrhythmia (1% to less than 10%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (1% to less than 10%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Grade 3 or 4 (36%), Febrile neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (10% to 16%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (18% to 45%), Pancytopenia (10%), Thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (49% to 67%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebral hemorrhage (1% to less than 10%), Seizure (1% to less than 10%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Although the exact mechanism of omacetaxine mepesuccinate has not been fully determined, it is a protein synthesis inhibitor with effect against chronic myelogenous leukemia independent of direct Bcr-Abl binding.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Plasma: hydrolysis via plasma esterases
  • 4'-DMHHT (major): activity unknown

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: less than 15% unchanged
  • Total body clearance: 177.4 mL/kg/hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    • use proper procedures for handling and disposal of chemotherapy
    • omacetaxine should be prepared in a healthcare facility by a healthcare professional; it may be administered at home in an appropriate candidate
  • Subcutaneous
    • reconstitute vial with 1 mL NS to yield a 3.5 mg/mL solution
    • gently swirl to solubilize powder (less than 1 minute)
    • use immediately or within 12 hours if stored at room temperature; use within 6 days (144 hours) if refrigerated

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• cytogenic and/or hematologic response indicate efficacy
  • CBC weekly at start of treatment and with initial maintenance cycles, then every 2 weeks or as clinically indicated; especially platelet count and differential
  • blood glucose levels frequently, especially in patients at-risk for or with diabetes

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn female patients of childbearing potential to avoid pregnancy as drug may cause fetal harm.
  • Instruct patient to report any upcoming dental or surgical procedures.
  • Advise nursing women to discontinue breastfeeding while receiving drug.
  • Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized as drug may cause fatigue.
  • Side effects may include fatigue, fever, asthenia, headache, diarrhea, nausea, and alopecia.
  • Tell patient to report redness, swelling, or pain at injection site
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of bleeding (eg, unusual bleeding, easy bruising) or myelosuppression (eg, fever, shortness of breath, fatigue).
  • Advise patient that this drug may cause glucose intolerance and hyperglycemia.
  • If home administration is required, train patient on proper handling, storage, administration, and disposal.
  • If a dose is missed, skip the missed dose and continue with the normal dosing schedule.
